chapterTitle: Introduction to Valuation:The Time Value of Money

columns.text: In this task, we are asked to explain why TMCC would be ready to take a small sum today in return for a commitment to repay about four times that amount in the future.

The most fundamental concept in the field of financial management is known as the "**time value of money**," which states that money obtained now is worth more than the same amount of money that will be received in the future. The reason for this is because there is the opportunity for the money to accumulate interest. As a consequence of this, the same amount of money received today will be worth more in the future.

In order to make an investment choice, one must use the notion of the time value of money to assess current and future cash inflows and outflows. The idea of the time value of money is useful for discounting and compounding cash flow statements.

TMCC's decision will be evaluated by finding the present value of the future payment in order to establish whether or not the choice that  made was the right one. Because there is just one cash flow, the present value of future payment will calculated in the following way:

$$\begin{align*}
\text{PV}=\dfrac{\text{FV}}{(1+\text{r})^\text{t}}
\end{align*}$$

Where:

PV = Present Value

FV = Future Value

r = Interest Rate

t = Number of years

Let's first identify the given amounts in a problem. For the purpose of evaluating the problem, the following values from Example 5.7 of the textbook would be used.

| |Amount/Value | 
|--|--| 
| Present Value |$24,099 | 
|Future Value |$100,000 | 
|Interest Rate | 10%| 
|Number of years | 25|

We will now substitute the values ​​in the equation from step 3 and calculate the present value of future payment as follows:

$$\begin{align*}
\text{PV}&=\dfrac{\$100,000}{(1+0.10)^{25}}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{\$100,000}{(1,10)^{25}}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{\$100,000}{10.84}\\[15pt]
&=\$9,225.09
\end{align*}$$

Therefore, the value of the future payment taken into account today is $9,229.60, which is less than the total amount of $24,099. As a result, the choice that TMCC made was the right one.
In this exercise, we will learn about the time value of money.

**Time value of money** is one of the core concepts in finance. According to it, the value of money received today is greater than the value of the same amount of money received in the future. The reason for this is the fact that we can earn a return if we invest the money today. For example, we can put the money in the bank and earn interest.

There exist two reasons why an investor should get an interest on the invested money: 
- First, everybody prefers present compared to future consumption. 
- Second, there is a possibility of inflation in the future period, which leads to the lower purchasing power of the money. Reduced purchasing power means that with the same amount of money an investor can buy fewer goods in the future than today.

Now, in order to answer why would TMCC accept the small amount of money in the present ($24,099) and promise to repay a much bigger amount of money in the future ($100,000) to the owner of its security, we should evaluate the cash flows by using the concept of the time value of money.

We will use the future value formula to determine what rate of return TMCC promises to its investor. **Future value** is the value that present money investment will have at a specific date in the future, given the interest rate and the number of interest periods. It can be calculated as follows:

$$\begin{aligned} 
\text{FV}&=\text{PV}\times\left(\text{1+r}\right)^\text{t}\\
 \end{aligned}\\ $$

Where:

FV = Future Value of Money (Cash Flow)\
PV = Present Value of Money (Cash Flow)\
r = Interest Rate\
t = Number of (Compounding) Periods

Next, let's identify the input variables in our problem:

|Variable | Value| 
|--|--| 
| Present Value| $24,099| 
| Future Value| $100,000| 
| Number of Periods|30 years |

After that, let's put the input values into our formula and rearrange it a little bit:
$$\begin{aligned} 
\text{FV}&=\text{PV}\times\left(\text{1+\text{r}}\right)^t\\[15pt]
\text{100,000}&=24,099\times\left(1+\text{r}\right)^{30}\\[15pt]
4.1495&=\left(1+\text{r}\right)^{30}\\
 \end{aligned}\\ $$

Now, we can solve the equation and find interest rate:
$$\begin{aligned} 

4.1495&=\left(1+\text{r}\right)^{30}\\[15pt]
4.1495^{1/30}&=1+\text{r}\\[15pt]
\text{r}&=4.1495^{1/30}-1\\[15pt]
\text{r}&=1.0486-1\\[15pt]
\text{r}&=\boxed{\bf0.0486\text{ \bf or 4.86\%}}\\
 \end{aligned}\\ $$

**In our problem, TMCC is practically promising an interest rate of 4.86 percent to its investor.**

So, if TMCC can invest the $24,099 received today from an investor and earn a rate of return higher than the 4.86 percent for the period of 30 years, it would make sense to go forward with this arrangement.

**To conclude, TMCC would be willing to accept $24,099 today in exchange for a promise to pay $100,000 in 30 years to an investor (the buyer of its security) if TMCC could invest money received today and get a return on its investment that is higher than the one promised to on investor**.
